article.Heading: Budget 2016 does well on flooring downside risks: CITI
article.Summary: he budget does well on flooring downside risks: the Fisc & macro stay controlled, in an uncertain growth/global environment, says CITI.
article.Body:
Consolidation over Consumption, and Cautious - It’s a budget that seeks fiscal consolidation (3.5 percent, ahead of market, impressive), does risk some segments of consumption, and focuses on process rather than pushing the boundaries – is cautious in its approach. This will keep India positioned and in play for upsides - but the budget is unlikely to fire the market or the mood.

The Big Picture: Consolidation — The budget takes a decisive call on fiscal consolidation: a) Stays on track with a 3.5 percent target (3.9 percent FY16, reasonable assumption – ex telecom); b) Bank capitalisation – Sticks with Rs 250b (commitment for more if needed) – will likely disappoint; and c) Agri, rural & roads spends – an economic & political focus, with some growth gains. The rating agencies & RBI should like this.

Tinkering with Taxes, and Consumption — The budget does tax in places: a) Consumption: Auto’s (cess), Jewellery (excise duty), Tobacco (+10 percent) High Networth’s (dividends): will hurt these sectors, b) Corporates: No reduction in corporate tax rate (1 percent indicated last year), dividend distribution while some exemptions have been removed (Pharma), and c) Some relief: Tax risks that do not play out (LT cap gains unchanged, 0.5 percent service tax instead of 2 percent). The consolidation gains risk some consumption pains.

Process Simplification & Institutionalization — This budget also seeks to focus on process – of tax resolutions (simplification, including voluntary disclosures), taxation (standardizing pension benefits, double taxation issues – REIT’s, ARC’s), and institutionalization (Bankruptcy norms – corporate/financial, Aadhar , PPP’s and DRT’s, bank consolidation ). These are all much needed & welcome changes for the Indian economy: their gains though will be longer term, than immediate.

Limits Downside Risks, But Also Upside Ones — The budget does well on flooring downside risks: the Fisc & macro stay controlled, in an uncertain growth/global environment. That said, it lacks growth impulses, is unlikely to (initself) spur economic or market momentum, and the equity market will need a more bottom up earnings / growth uptick, to respond to what should be a stable top down India. Maintain positive view on India, with a 27,200 Dec 16 Sensex target.
